Definition: The input contains an argument and a keypoint on the topic "We should fight for the abolition of nuclear weapons", separated by "<sep>".Your task is to answer if the keypoint matches the argument and summarizes exactly what the argument means, in the contextof this topic.

Positive Examples.input: Argument: If at least one-tenth of the money and efforts we put into constructing nuclear weapons and anti-missile systems went into promoting disarmament and mutual trust, the global peace would long have been achieved.<sep>Keypoint: Nuclear weapons can fall into the wrong hands
Positive Examples.explanation: The keypoint does not summarize the argument that if at least one-tenth of the money and efforts we put into constructing nuclear weapons and anti-missile systems went into promoting disarmament and mutual trust, the global peace would long have been achieved.

Positive Examples.input: Argument: As it is becoming increasingly obvious that they are too dangerous to keep. they cause devastating destruction and in the wrong hands could cause the end of the world.<sep>Keypoint: Nuclear weapons can fall into the wrong hands
Positive Examples.explanation: The keypoint summarizes the argument that as it is becoming increasingly obvious that they are too dangerous to keep. they cause devastating destruction and in the wrong hands could cause the end of the world.

Positive Examples.input: Argument: Nuclear weapons also provide a safety net for countries in case of an attack and should not be banned.<sep>Keypoint: Nuclear weapons is essential for protection and deterrence
Positive Examples.explanation: The keypoint summarizes the argument that nuclear weapons also provide a safety net for countries in case of an attack and should not be banned.

Negative Examples.input: Argument: Nothing good comes from nuclear weapons. humans need to get along and work together for a better world instead of finding new ways to destroy the enemy.<sep>Keypoint: Nuclear weapons can fall into the wrong hands
Negative Examples.explanation: The keypoint does not summarize the argument that nothing good comes from nuclear weapons. humans need to get along and work together for a better world instead of finding new ways to destroy the enemy.

Negative Examples.input: Argument: Nuclear weapons help to insure that other countries will not attach because they in turn will most certainly be destroyed.<sep>Keypoint: Nuclear weapons is essential for protection and deterrence
Negative Examples.explanation: The keypoint summarizes the argument that nuclear weapons help to insure that other countries will not attach because they in turn will most certainly be destroyed.

Negative Examples.input: Argument: Nuclear weapons are one of the biggest threats facing humanity today. abolishing them would eliminate that threat.<sep>Keypoint: Nuclear weapons can fall into the wrong hands
Negative Examples.explanation: The keypoint does not summarize the argument that nuclear weapons are one of the biggest threats facing humanity today. abolishing them would eliminate that threat.
